text: Family Member: Now, at the end of the trial catheter, how do they go uh with that? Do they have to wait for the catheter to come out in order start clinical trials or or, Doctor: That’s after you’ve sat down with D and signed the paperwork. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then they’ll do the extra tests to see that you’re eligible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there are steps and then if you’re working with a urologist and he or she is able to get it out, that’s great. If they feel like it needs to stay in and that isn’t something that excludes you from the study or that just will tell me that if I’m giving you chemotherapy your blood counts can get low. If your blood counts are low and you’ve got a tube in your bladder, you could have an infection. So that I might give you antibiotics to keep you from getting an infection because you’ve got the tube in. Patient: Um. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it just lets me be aware that I’ve got to be extra careful I’m giving you the chemotherapy. But it could be the one thing that sort of says oh he’s not eligible because he’s got a tube in his body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or maybe they don’t care one bit. Patient: Um.

text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We always got to watch your blood counts, because we always got to watch your blood counts. And that means white cells, red cells, platelets, and then of course, liver and kidney numbers. But that's blood tests. So you don't necessarily feel bad from that. We do know that some patients, their platelets go down a little bit. And that in some other patients, you might get a little bit of stomach upset. So not like full blown oh my gosh, you can't eat anything. And if that is the case, then we would have to, you know, modify the medication dose. But you can get a slight, you know, nausea or upset stomach. So we'd have to figure out how that plays with you. Other than that, that’s about it, so it's basically another hormone pill. So Xtandi, tackles one pathway of the receptor. This pill is another pathway. They are somewhat related, but this is not a chemo, it's actually another hormone. Yeah. So we're just trying to make sure you're super castrated, and then some, and then some. Patient: There’s that euphemism for the Prius. Patient: So, how does it affect my heart? Doctor: So obviously, we have to make sure that we take care of it, it shouldn't affect there's no direct effect, you know, it's not like, here's the chemo and Oh, boy. The Xtandi is, you know, always has a potential for heart issues, because we can't say that it doesn't, because anything that touches that testosterone pathway puts you in more of a menopause and accelerates heart disease. But that's true with your, you know, Lupron, that's true for all the other pills you've been on. Unfortunately, that's the main sort of active drug with all of this with prostate cancer. So that's the tough part. This one shouldn't have a cardiac thing. But again, this is a study. So if you do have a worsening cardiac thing that's reportable, because we would want to make sure that no other person has that. Patient: So they don't know that? Doctor: Oh, no, this is why it's a study. I mean, this is- you’re guinea pig, once again, you know, like you tell us what's going on. But it isn't like this is a chemo or something that we're really worried that this might worsen heart disease. But it's always this- every time you fool around with the hormone receptors, you know, it can worsen heart disease in general. So I don't know about this particular combo, but that's why it's on a study and not me just go in here, take this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What else? Patient: And for how long does this study last? Doctor: As long as you respond, we keep going. So if you are side effects, or too much, or you're like, Listen, I'm just done, we stop. If you say my gosh, this thing is really good. And I'm doing great, we keep going. And it's we can't take the drug away from you. Sometimes that's to the irritation of the pharma company, because sometimes they want to get out after a year, but it's actually interesting. One of my other studies, somebody's been on two years longer than they thought, and they want to close it. And we're like, well, I'm sorry, my one guy's doing great. So you can't take it away from us. So there's that other option, but in general, it's you who calls it quits or that the cancer’s has moved on. And if that's happened, we got to stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Mhm.

text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - your PSA was a fourteen in September and then it was twenty-eight January. So in a four-month period your PSA went up one hundred percent. It doubled. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So based on that trajectory, if I had to guess, your PSA is still at the same place, so to speak, it will take about half that amount of time for your PSA to go about fifty percent. So if it goes - you’re expected to go up fifty percent … for a year, two years Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So that’s the general, overall, design of the trial. And um because the trial involves radiation therapy being delivered by a radiology oncologist. And would and the ORIOLE study as they call it, is being run by one of the radiology oncologists called Dr. T. You’ll see his name here. And, the way that we would precede, if you wanted me to, is to after we have this conversation… to give you the consent form, read it very carefully. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Um to arrange a consultation, or a timely consultation with Dr. T in his clinic, which is in the building. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And, on that particular day you would have read out any particular information about the trial and issue questions for him and his team. Um, and if those questions aren’t answered to your satisfaction go ahead and do that. Then after that you’ve basically completed the screening for randomization. Okay. So although the study is a randomized study, it’s not a blinded study. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But in the case of radiotherapy versus therapy,

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
